textRegions.text: learning the basics of vector math in jME3
What vectors are and how to create them
How to add, subtract, multiply and normalize vectors
What quaternions are and how to create them
How to rotate a vector using a quaternion
How to use lookAt to create rotations
Vectors can define locations, directions, forces and more.
A vector contains three values: X, Y and Z
The length of a vector is another important value that is dependent on the X, Y and Z values
Vector3f vectorA = new Vector3f(0, 1, 0); creates a vector with values 0, 1, 0
Vector3f vectorB = new Vector3f(1, 0, 0); creates a vector with values 1, 0, 0
Vector3f vectorC = new Vector3f(0, 0, 1); creates a vector with values 0, 0, 1 (towards you)
Vector3f vectorD = new Vector3f(-1, 0, 0); creates a vector with values -1, 0, 0
all these vectors have a length of 1
Vector3f vectorE = new Vector3f(1, 1, 0); creates a vector with values 1, 1, 0
This vector has a length of 1.4 because
adding, subtracting, multiplying and normalizing vectors
Vector3f vectorA = new Vector3f(0, 1, 0); creates a new vector with x, y, z values 0, 1, 0
Vector3f vectorB = new Vector3f(1, 0, 0); creates a new vector with x, y, z values 1, 0, 0
Vector3f vectorC = vectorA.add(vectorB); adds vectorA and vectorB
the resulting x, y, z values of vectorC are 1, 1, 0
the length of the vector is 1.4
Vector3f vectorC = vectorA.subtract(vectorB); subtracting vectorB from vectorA can be imagined as the vector between the tip of vectorB and vectorA
the resulting x, y, z values of vectorC are -1, 1, 0
the length of the vector is 1.4
Vector3f vectorA = new Vector3f(1, 0, 0); creates a vector with values 1, 0, 0
Vector3f vectorB = vectorA.mult(1.5f); multiplies the length of the vector with 1.5
the resulting x, y, z values of vectorB are 1.5, 0, 0
the length of the vector is 1.5
Vector3f vectorA = new Vector3f(1, 1, 0); creates a vector with values 1, 1, 0
The length of this vector is 1.4
Vector3f vectorB = vectorA.normalize(); normalizes the length of vectorA to 1
the resulting x, y, z values of vectorB are 0.7, 0.7, 0
the length of the vector is 1 (its a normalized vector)
Vector3f vectorC = FastMath.interpolateLinear(0.5f,vectorA,vectorB); interpolates the center location between vectorA and vectorB
the resulting x, y, z values of vectorC are 0.5, 0.5, 0
the length of the vector is 0.7
vectorC = FastMath.interpolateLinear(0.75f, vectorA, vectorB); interpolates the location at 3/4 between vectorA and vectorB
the resulting x, y, z values of vectorC are 0.75, 0.25, 0.0
the length of the vector is 0.79
Quaternions can be created using amounts of rotation around the three axes
Quaternion quatA = new Quaternion(); quatA.fromAngleAxis(FastMath.HALF_PI, Vector3f.UNIT_Z); creates a new quaternion with a rotation of 90 around the Z axis
Quaternion quatB = new Quaternion(); quatB.fromAngleAxis(FastMath.QUARTER_PI, Vector3f.UNIT_Y); creates a new quaternion with a rotation of 45 around the Y axis

Quaternion quatC = new Quaternion(); float[] angles = new float[]{FastMath.HALF_PI, FastMath.PI, FastMath.PI}; quat.fromAngles(angles); creates a new quaternion with a rotation of 90 around the X axis, 180 around the Y axis and 180 around the Z axis
Vector3f vectorA = new Vector3f(0, 1, 0); creates a new vector with x, y, z values 0, 1, 0
Quaternion roll45 = new Quaternion(); roll45.fromAngleAxis(-FastMath.QUARTER_PI, Vector3f.UNIT_Z); creates a new quaternion and sets the rotation to -45 around the Z axis
Vector3f vectorB = roll45.mult(vectorA); rotates vectorA using the quaternion roll45
the resulting x, y, z values of vectorB are 0.7, 0.7, 0
the length of the vector is 1
You can concatenate quaternions by multiplying them
This is not commutative, so A x B != B x A
For A x B the resulting C is a rotation first around A and then around B
Quaternion quatA = new Quaternion(); quatA.fromAngleAxis(-FastMath.HALF_PI, Vector3f.UNIT_Z); creates a new quaternion with a rotation of -90 around the Z axis
Quaternion quatB = new Quaternion(); quatB.fromAngleAxis(-FastMath.HALF_PI, Vector3f.UNIT_Y); creates a new quaternion with a rotation of -90 around the Y axis
Quaternion quatC = quatA.mult(quatB); multiplies quatA x quatB
Vector3f vectorA = new Vector3f(0, 1, 0); creates a new vector with x, y, z values 0, 1, 0
Vector3f vectorB = quatC.mult(vectorA); multiplies the resulting quatC with vectorA to rotate it
the result vector is rotated 90 around the x axis
in step 1 the vector is rotated around the z axis by the quatA component
in step 2 the result vector is rotated around the y axis by the quatB component
the resulting x, y, z values of vectorB are 0, 0, 1 (towards you)
the length of the vector is 1
quatC rotated vectorA 90 around the x axis
now we multiply B x A
quatC = quatB.mult(quatA); multiplies quatB x quatA
Vector3f vectorA = new Vector3f(0, 1, 0); creates a new vector with x, y, z values 0, 1, 0
Vector3f vectorB = quatC.mult(vectorA); multiplies the resulting quatC with vectorA to rotate it
the result vector is rotated -90 around the z axis
in step 1 the vector is rotated around the y axis by the quatB component
in this example, nothing happens as the vector points upwards
in step 2 the result vector is rotated around the z axis by the quatA component
the resulting x, y, z values of vectorB are 1, 0, 0
the length of the vector is 1
quatC rotated vectorA -90 around the z axis
Do not try to set rotation on your spatials by combining or storing rotations
Best use direction and up vectors and convert them to Quaternions when you need them
The lookAt method allows to do this easily (see next chapter)
Using lookAt to create a Quaternion
lookAt creates a quaternion from an up vector and a look direction
the resulting quaternion rotates a vector that is perpendicular to the up vector into the direction of the direction vector
lookAt is mainly used for rotating spatials where y = up and z = forward
Vector3f upVector = new Vector3f(0, 1, 0); Vector3f direction = new Vector3f(1, 0, 0); creates the up and direction vectors
Quaternion quat = new Quaternion(); quat.lookAt(direction, upVector); creates a new quaternion from the direction and up vectors
remember the resulting quaternion should rotate a vector that is perpendicular (around x) to the upVector ...
... towards the direction of the direction vector
so the resulting quaternion is a rotation of 90 around the y axis in this case
the resulting quaternion can for example be used to rotate a spatial with zero rotation (facing in z direction) towards the direction of the direction vector
the lookAt method available on spatials generates the direction vector based on the world location of the spatial and the supplied location vector
this allows to quickly rotate the spatial towards a certain location

Thank you for reading, I hope this gave you a good start into jME3 math, any input is very welcome - Normen
